Award.AwardTitle: Combinatorics in geometry and algebra with applications to the natural sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mathematically, the research focuses on interactions between combinatorics, geometry, and algebra. The projects are centered around specific applications to natural sciences, including evolutionary biology, medical imaging, dynamics of chemical reactions, algorithms and computational complexity, and theoretical high-energy physics. More specifically, the projects include: (1) algorithms for finding centroids in spaces of phylogenetic trees, and general gradient optimization methods for piecewise differentiable functions on polyhedral spaces, with applications to evolutionary biology and medical imaging, and to computational complexity of convex polyhedral spheres; (2) applications of commutative algebra of binomials to dynamics and stability of mass action kinetics in chemistry; (3) efficient algorithms for combinatorial game theory using connections to commutative algebra, based on techniques involving generating functions; and (4) commutative algebra and algebraic geometry of algebraic varieties, with large group actions, arising in high-energy physics.

Interactions between modern combinatorics, geometry, and algebra have become increasingly rich in recent years. This research will explore and deepen these connections at their interfaces with a number of other disciplines, including biology, chemistry, physics, computer science, statistics, and operations research. The specific mathematical projects focus on computational geometry and optimization; the algebra of polynomials; and smooth geometry in the presence of symmetry. Despite the range of the proposed intellectual activities in mathematics and its applications, they are drawn together by unifying themes in geometry and algebra. By supporting personnel (undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers), this project will have substantial positive effects on education through research in the aforementioned areas. Fostering ties between these areas, among personnel as well as in scientific discovery, is an explicit, central objective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the research lay in its exploration and
deepening of interactions between modern combinatorics, geometry, and
algebra, in mathematical projects ranging from computational geometry
and optimization on spaces composed of flat pieces to algebra and
geometry of solutions to highly symmetric polynomial systems of
equations, especially decompositions of the solution sets into
manageable, understandable pieces.  The mathematical projects resulted
in specific applications to natural sciences, including algorithms and
computational complexity for combinatorial games, stability theorems
for dynamics of chemical reactions, algorithms for averaging
phylogenetic trees, and statistical methodology for medical imaging of
brain arteries.  The latter two projects involved statistical analysis
in contexts where the data objects or sets of data objects are
singularly geometric in nature, a theme which this research initiated
and developed in abstract mathematical ways.

The broader impact contributions of the project fell under six
categories: (i) mentoring undergraduates, graduate students, and
postdoctoral researchers, particularly by integrating these activities
with specific proposed research projects; (ii) expository work,
including lectures and minicourses as well as written books and
expository articles; (iii) organizing opportunities for learning and
spreading research, such as workshops, summer schools, and
conferences; (iv) interdisciplinary activities that enhance
connections between mathematics and the sciences; and (v) outreach,
including lectures by the PI to audiences composed of high-school
teachers or high-school students, organization of a public lecture by
a prominent local TV chief meteorologist about conveying uncertainty
to the public, subsequent consultation by the PI with the
meteorologist and his team about how to present data uncertainty for
primetime on-air public consumption, and mass-media publication of an
analysis by the PI concerning how to estimate the odds of winning
Warren Buffett's $1 billion payout for a perfect NCAA basketball
bracket; and finally (vi) participation in development of a university
program that prepares middle-school STEM teachers for the challenging
Durham Public Schools environment.

By supporting personnel, the requested funds had substantial positive
effect on education and outreach through research in combinatorics,
geometry, algebra, and their interfaces with a number of scientific
disciplines, including biology, medicine, chemistry, computer science,
operations research, and statistics.
